prohibition_era.significance: St. Paul Agreement - safe haven for gangsters
prohibition_era.description: Under corrupt police chief John "The Big Fellow" O'Connor, St. Paul became a safe haven for criminals who agreed not to commit crimes within city limits

notable_criminals.name: John Dillinger
events: Dillinger gang shootout at Lincoln Court (March 31, 1934)

notable_criminals.name: Ma Barker and the Barker-Karpis Gang
notable_criminals.description: Used St. Paul as planning headquarters for kidnappings and bank robberies

notable_criminals.name: Baby Face Nelson
notable_criminals.description: Frequently used St. Paul as hideout between robberies

notable_criminals.name: Alvin "Creepy" Karpis
notable_criminals.description: Key member of Barker-Karpis gang, operated from St. Paul

notable_criminals.name: Leon Gleckman
notable_criminals.description: St. Paul's most powerful bootlegger and gangster coordinator

locations.name: Hollyhocks Club
locations.description: Illegal casino and nightclub frequented by gangsters

locations.name: Green Lantern Saloon
locations.description: Gangster meeting place, owned by Harry Sawyer

end_of_era.result: Federal crackdown on organized crime in St. Paul

notable_cases.description: Gang members fled through Minnesota after failed Northfield bank robbery
notable_cases.connection: Some members had St. Paul connections

notable_cases.description: Massive corruption revealed in police department

crime_statistics_historical.homicide_rate_1930s: Among highest in nation during gangster era
crime_statistics_historical.bootlegging: Major distribution hub for illegal alcohol
